discussion.content:
Incident response policies: When an incident occurs, all employees should
understand it is their responsibility to be on the lookout for it and report it
immediately to the appropriate party

questions.question_text: A network administrator wants to ensure sensitive data is not exfiltrated from the system electronically. Which of the following should be implemented?

discussion.content:
DLP is the most correct solution. Data Loss Prevention can be a hardware or software solution that actively combs outbound traffic, including email, for sensitive data and stops any violating traffic.
AUP is incorrect; while an acceptable use policy would strongly deter would-be leakers, it does not do so outright.
NDA is incorrect. A non-disclosure agreement would legally prohibit internal staff from divulging sensitive information it does not do so outright, legal interventions aside.
SLA is incorrect. A service level agreement is a contract between a service provider and client on what each party expects from the other (money for Internet access and tech support, mean time between failures, expected downtime, etc.)
I'm wondering how DLP is related to networking, since it's a security engineering/endpoint management/policy job.
Answer: A

Otherwise, for a wired network, only blocking unused ports on the switch wud help in this case.

discussion.content: The answer doesn't really stop people from connecting their personal equipment to the network. They just need to ensure they're using secure protocols. That doesn't fulfill the requirement of not letting them connect. ???

Selected Answer: A
Come on man it's definitely A for unused ports on switch.

Selected Answer: A
only A
Got this question on the exam. I went with force users to use captive portal as an answer choice. Should of gone with shut down unused ports. Smh
I would have expected to see an option like MAC Filtering here.
the main point in the question is "bypass some of the security protocols on their desktops"

"management has asked that users not be allowed to attach personal devices to the network". How in the world C is correct ? Allowing only secure protocols doesn't prevent users from attaching their devices. If we're talking about LAN, answer A would fit. If we're talking about WLAN also, well, none of these answers make sense.

comments.content: Does C make sense? i mean you could just use Secure protocols on your own device?

Tell me if you have a secure protocol on your laptop, then ask everyone else. How can it be C when this doesn't make sense. They said attached devices... Disable the unused port on the switch is such a better answer.

discussion.content: C because no other answer makes sense.
there is no mention of WiFi only "attach" personal devices to the network - Answer A

comments.content: Personal devices may mean devices like smartphones and tablets, So these devices cannot connect using wire...Therefore it implicitly referred to wireless.

This is another bad framed question. It clearly says at the begining "In the past, users brought personal laptops", so you can't just not consider laptops with RJ45/ethernet connectors, even if there's some models that doesn't include them nowdays, on the real world, you can still attach a USB adapter and use it. So disabling switchports is a best practice and the only action that will make sense in this context. The same protocols, secure or not, that runs in a corporate device will also run in a personal device. So allowing only secure protocols, although a best practice as well, doesn't prevent users from attaching devices to the network. It might increase the difficulties to make it work, but they will still be able to use it.

discussion.content:
A. Shut down unused ports on switches (Users can connect wirelessly and donot need a ethernet connection so this option is kind of useless)
 B. Upgrade firmware on network devices (It won't help)
 C. Allow only secure protocols on the network (This is the only option left)
 D. Disable unnecessary services (It won't help)

I would go for "B" because other options will not help in this scenario.

comments.content: Sorry a typo " I would go with C"

This is making the assumption that the network has WLAN capabilities, and while most do, it is not a safe assumption to make with CompTIA. Because the objective is to prevent personal devices from being ATTACHED to the network and not simply securing personal devices, I would think A is the best answer.

choices.C: Allow only secure protocols on the network
choices.A: Shut down unused ports on switches

questions.question_text: In the past, users brought personal laptops to the office to bypass some of the security protocols on their desktops. Due to new security initiatives, management has asked that users not be allowed to attach personal devices to the network. Which of the following should a technician use to BEST meet this goal?
A technician is installing a SOHO router. Which of the following should be performed on every installation and periodically maintained to prevent unauthorized access? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: If E was one of the options which I wouldn't be surprised if CompTIA tried to pull, I would have smashed this computer

while disabling SSID will help, you have to pay attention to what the question is asking you. 

Something that should be performed on every installation is a firmware update.

Something that needs to be done periodically meaning from time to time would be changing your password. You aren't going to periodically disable SSID since that is just a one-go feature. So the answer is correct.

comments.content: every installation " is you have to change the password of the router and update the frimware" comptia A+
Why would you disable SSID and change your password, makes no sense...

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
DION mentioned many times that COMPTia wants U to know that SSID broadcast disable is a security feature, so I would choose this instead of firmware on he exam
I think that the use of complex passwords is another way to say "delete default credentials like username: admin & password: admin" so yeah, seems to be correct.
